docs.snippet: AS much as anybody, Julianne Moore knows that a part can live on. Especially after her experience on the daytime drama ''As the World Turns.'' In 1985 Ms. Moore played the dual role of the good girl Frannie and her mysterious, identical, British h...
docs.lead_paragraph: AS much as anybody, Julianne Moore knows that a part can live on. Especially after her experience on the daytime drama ''As the World Turns.'' In 1985 Ms. Moore played the dual role of the good girl Frannie and her mysterious, identical, British half-sister Sabrina, who, in true soap fashion, was selfish and evil. Ms. Moore was so adept at making her characters' melodramatic existences plausible that in 1988 she was awarded a daytime Emmy, although she wasn't present at the ceremony to pick up her statuette. By then, she had left the show and was rehearsing the role of Ophelia in ''Hamlet'' at the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis. As for the soap opera, the show carried on with the new Frannie and Sabrina, even though the characters looked nothing like Ms. Moore or, for that matter, each other. ''They hired two different actresses to replace me,'' Ms. Moore said. ''That was very, very flattering.''
docs.abstract: Julianne Moore talks about getting lead role in movie Hannibal, to play character created by Jodie Foster in 1991 movie Silence of the Lambs; photo (M)

headline.main: Hello Again, Clarice, But You've Changed

docs.snippet: THE framed photographs displayed on the grand piano in her Beverly Hills home tell the story: Elizabeth Taylor, Jimmy Stewart, Cary Grant, to name a few. Growing up in Los Angeles, Carrie Fisher, daughter of Debbie Reynolds and Eddie Fisher, had a...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE framed photographs displayed on the grand piano in her Beverly Hills home tell the story: Elizabeth Taylor, Jimmy Stewart, Cary Grant, to name a few. Growing up in Los Angeles, Carrie Fisher, daughter of Debbie Reynolds and Eddie Fisher, had a front-row seat for the behind-the-scenes doings in the entertainment industry. As a screenwriter and in her best-selling semiautobiographical novels, including ''Postcards From the Edge,'' which was made into a film starring Meryl Streep and Shirley MacLaine, Ms. Fisher has used her Hollywood insider's life as rich comic fodder.
docs.abstract: Carrie Fisher's screenplay for television movie These Old Broads features Debbie Reynolds, Shirley MacLaine and Joan Collins as icons; photos (M)

headline.main: Writing a Show for Mom and Her Friends

docs.snippet: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.  + means discounted tickets were at the Theater Devel...
docs.lead_paragraph: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show. + means discounted tickets were at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights. ++ means tickets were at the TKTS booth for last Friday night only. Broadway *++ ''CONTACT.'' More than a year after opening, Susan Stroman's sparkling anthem to the transforming powers of dance has yet to succumb to the anemia that often befalls long-running musicals. A recent visit to this Tony Award-winning show found it in a robust, muscle-flexing state of health. This three-part self-described dance play has ripened into mellowness, with a newly relaxed expansiveness that doesn't dilute its intoxication factor. The attitude speaks of performers who are so comfortable with the contours of their parts that they can riff on them a bit, sounding new emotional notes. The original stars -- Karen Ziemba, Boyd Gaines and Deborah Yates -- are still on board and clearly delighted to be there, as is most of the original ensemble. An ideal, blood-warming winter alternative to a Caribbean weekend (2:00). Beaumont, Lincoln Center, (212) 239-6200. Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m. Tickets: $55 and $85 (Ben Brantley).

docs.snippet: In Ridley Scott's ''Hannibal,'' Anthony Hopkins (below) takes a second helping of the role that won him an Oscar in ''The Silence of the Lambs.'' This time, the chianti should be ever so much more accessible, since Dr. Lecter has moved to Florence...
docs.lead_paragraph: In Ridley Scott's ''Hannibal,'' Anthony Hopkins (below) takes a second helping of the role that won him an Oscar in ''The Silence of the Lambs.'' This time, the chianti should be ever so much more accessible, since Dr. Lecter has moved to Florence, Italy. Can the F.B.I. agent Clarice Starling (Julianne Moore) be far behind? Elvis Mitchell's review, Page 12.

docs.snippet: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of film...
docs.lead_paragraph: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 9. Now Playing * ''BEFORE NIGHT FALLS,'' starring Javier Bardem and Johnny Depp. Directed by Julian Schnabel (R, 125 minutes). Mr. Schnabel's romanticized portrait of the exiled gay Cuban poet and novelist Reinaldo Arenas, who committed suicide while suffering from AIDS, imagines pre-Castro Cuba as a pagan paradise of endless erotic promise ruined by the puritanical Communists, whom Arenas embraced, then turned against. Mr. Bardem's arresting performance paints Arenas as an emotionally volatile daredevil. But this biography, which incorporates swaths of Arenas's writing, is sketchy, and the star's thick Spanish accent is daunting. It's still quite indelible (Stephen Holden).

docs.snippet: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.    Opera    ''UN BALLO IN MASCHERA.'' Verdi's ''Ballo'' is an elegant opera, but this reviva...
docs.lead_paragraph: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region. Opera ''UN BALLO IN MASCHERA.'' Verdi's ''Ballo'' is an elegant opera, but this revival is blunt rather than elegant, like a lump of rock shot through with a few veins of gold. The Met has managed to find three genuine Verdi voices for the three main roles, but none of them sing with particular elegance or flair; the only real emotional impact comes from the Ulrica of Elena Zaremba. It doesn't help that the conductor, Plácido Domingo, seems to react to the score rather than leading it. The Oscar of Youngok Shin is something else again: a sprite on rubber legs cavorting around the stage, acting out her notes more than singing them, she seems descended from another planet. Tomorrow at 1:30 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House; (212) 362-6000. Only standing-room tickets, $12 and $16 (Anne Midgette).

docs.snippet: Oscar De La Hoya spoke of retiring last June after losing his World Boxing Council welterweight title to Sugar Shane Mosley. Yesterday, De La Hoya spoke with enthusiasm about his return to the ring on March 24 in a 12-round welterweight fight agai...
docs.lead_paragraph: Oscar De La Hoya spoke of retiring last June after losing his World Boxing Council welterweight title to Sugar Shane Mosley. Yesterday, De La Hoya spoke with enthusiasm about his return to the ring on March 24 in a 12-round welterweight fight against Arturo Gatti, the former International Boxing Federation junior-lightweight champion, at the MGM Grand in Las Vegas. ''Let me clear one thing up: I was never retired,'' De La Hoya said during a conference call with reporters to promote the fight. ''I was just on a little vacation to regroup myself, so I could relax physically, mentally to see what I really want in boxing.''
docs.abstract: Oscar De La Hoya to fight Arturo Gotti on March 24 in a 12-round welterweight fight in Las Vegas (S)

headline.main: De La Hoya's Vacation Is Over
